title: Linear and rotation - car acceleration from theta

content.question: A car with tires of radius <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is moving along a straight road. Each tire’s angular displacement is given by the equation <math alttext="theta equals A t raised to the 4 power, plus B t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is time and <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> and are constants with appropriate units. The tires do not slip on the road’s surface. What is the car’s acceleration as a function of time?
